Description: Fragment of a minature terracotta tragic mask. Wide round eyes, furrowed brow and open mouth. Mould-made, pressed into one-piece mould, with simple back. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt with lime inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from same mould dated to the Ptolemaic period (Fischer 1994, no.348). A small number of tragedy masks and figures of actors wearing tragedy masks are known from Naukratis (Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.301.1899; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.463; Dundee, McManus Galleries 1975-166). Comedy was more commonly depicted. Fischer, J. 1994, Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber, Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen, Tübinger Studien zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte 14, Tübingen. Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.306) (Phase 3)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.701, table 8.18, no.2)
